ground_truth: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls emitting blaring jazz music. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's establishment, and the motion picture theatre has become a burlesque house. George stops before the former offices of the Building and Loan, where a crowd watches the police raiding the place, dragging screaming women into a patrol wagon, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a tart. George talks to one of the cops but is shoved aside. He notices Ernie's taxi cruising by, which stops to pick him up. As Ernie drives, he spots Bert the cop by his police car and signals him to follow, indicating a problematic passenger. Bert follows in his car as the taxi parks at the curb, and George exits to look at a house, momentarily stopped by its dilapidated appearance with broken windows, sagging porch, fallen roof section, and askew doors and shutters. The police car arrives and Bert and Ernie watch George, who approaches the house like a doomed man. Ernie uses his cab's spotlight to illuminate the house's interior ghostlike. George cries out, appearing like a call for help. Clarence suddenly leans against a wall as Bert, with gun in hand, stands in the entrance and rushes toward him. Ernie follows closely, ready to assist. Bert tries to lead George away, but George struggles to explain, prompting Bert to raise his gun intending to strike George. Clarence intervenes, biting Bert's wrist, allowing George to escape the house and run down the street while Bert and Clarence wrestle, falling to the ground. Bert attempts to handcuff Clarence, but Clarence disappears, leaving Bert amazed before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, George runs up the path and knocks on the door of the house.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The scenario commences with a sequence of images portraying nightclubs, eateries, pubs, liquor outlets, and billiard parlors emitting blaring jazz melodies. Gower's chemist's shop is now a pawnbroker's establishment, and the cinema has turned into a burlesque theater. George halts in front of the previous offices of the Construction and Loan, where a throng observes the constabulary raiding the premises, pulling shrieking women into a patrol van, including Violet Bick, who is attired as a harlot. George converses with one of the officers but is thrust aside. He perceives Ernie's cab cruising by, which stops to collect him. As Ernie drives, he recognizes Bert the officer by his squad car and signals him to pursue, indicating a troublesome rider. Bert follows in his vehicle as the cab stops at the edge, and George exits to inspect a dwelling, momentarily halted by its decrepit appearance with fractured windows, drooping porch, collapsed roof segment, and misaligned doors and shutters. The squad car arrives and Bert and Ernie observe George, who approaches the dwelling like a condemned individual. Ernie utilizes his taxi's spotlight to illuminate the house's interior spectrally. George cries out, appearing like a plea for aid. Clarence abruptly leans against a barrier as Bert, with weapon in hand, stands in the entryway and charges toward him. Ernie follows closely, prepared to assist. Bert attempts to lead George away, but George struggles to articulate, prompting Bert to elevate his firearm intending to hit George. Clarence intervenes, biting Bert's wrist, allowing George to flee the house and dash down the street while Bert and Clarence grapple, collapsing to the ground. Bert endeavors to shackle Clarence, but Clarence vanishes, leaving Bert astonished before he departs from the scenario. Meanwhile, George sprints up the path and raps on the door of the dwelling.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The scene is begun with a series of shots that depict night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls from which blaring jazz music is emitted. Gower's drugstore has now been turned into a pawnbroker's establishment, and the motion picture theatre is turned into a burlesque house. The former offices of the Building and Loan are stopped before by George, where the police are watched by a crowd as they raid the place, dragging screaming women into a patrol wagon, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a tart. One of the cops is talked to by George, but he shoves him aside. Ernie's taxi is noticed by him, cruising by, and it stops to pick him up. Bert the cop is spotted by Ernie as he drives, and he signals him to follow, indicating a problematic passenger. He follows in his car as the taxi is parked at the curb, and George exits to look at a house, which is momentarily stopped by him due to its dilapidated appearance with broken windows, sagging porch, fallen roof section, and askew doors and shutters. The police car is arrived, and Bert and Ernie watch George, who approaches the house like a doomed man. The cab's spotlight is used by Ernie to illuminate the house's interior ghostlike. George cries out, and it appears like a call for help. Suddenly, Clarence leans against a wall as Bert, with gun in hand, stands in the entrance and rushes toward him. He is followed closely by Ernie, ready to assist. George is tried to be led away by Bert, but George struggles to explain, prompting Bert to raise his gun intending to strike George. Bert's wrist is bitten by Clarence, allowing George to escape the house and run down the street while Bert and Clarence wrestle, falling to the ground. Clarence is attempted to be handcuffed by Bert, but he disappears, leaving Bert amazed before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, up the path runs George and he knocks on the door of the house.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The scene opens with shots of nightclubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls blaring jazz music. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnshop, and the theater is a burlesque house. George pauses before the former Building and Loan office, watching police raid it and haul screaming women, including the tart-dressed Violet Bick, into a patrol wagon. George speaks to a cop but is pushed aside. Ernie's taxi drives by and picks him up. Ernie signals Bert the cop to follow them, hinting at a troublesome passenger. As they park, George is taken aback by a dilapidated house with broken windows and a sagging porch. Bert and Ernie observe as George approaches the house, appearing distressed. Ernie uses his cab spotlight to eerily illuminate the interior. George cries out for help. Clarence leans against a wall as Bert rushes in with a gun, followed by Ernie. Bert tries to detain George, but Clarence intervenes, biting Bert's wrist, enabling George to flee. Bert and Clarence struggle, and Clarence vanishes, leaving Bert astonished before exiting the scene. Meanwhile, George knocks on the house door.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The scene starts with shots of night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls blasting jazz music. A drugstore is now a pawnbroker, and the movie theatre is a burlesque house. George sees the Building and Loan offices, where police are arresting women, including tart-dressed Violet Bick. A cop shoves George aside. Ernie's taxi picks up George, who signals Bert the cop to follow due to a problem. They stop at a dilapidated house. Ernie illuminates the house as George cries out, and Clarence leans against a wall. Bert, gun drawn, rushes in, with Ernie close behind. Bert tries to lead George away, but George resists. Clarence intervenes, biting Bert’s wrist, allowing George to flee. Bert and Clarence wrestle until Clarence vanishes. Amazed, Bert leaves. George knocks on the house door.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
The scene unfolds with a captivating sequence of shots that vividly portray the vibrant nightlife of the city, showcasing a variety of night clubs, bustling cafes, lively bars, overflowing liquor stores, and bustling pool halls, all resounding with the energetic and blaring sounds of jazz music. In the midst of this nocturnal commotion, Gower’s drugstore has undergone a transformation and now serves as a pawnbroker's shop, while the once-popular motion picture theatre has been converted into a house of burlesque. George comes to a stop in front of what once were the offices of the Building and Loan, where a crowd has gathered to observe the police conducting a raid. The officers are forcefully dragging out women who are screaming in protest, among them Violet Bick, conspicuously dressed as a tart. George tries to engage one of the police officers in conversation but is roughly shoved aside. He then notices Ernie’s taxi cruising by and makes a signal, causing it to stop and pick him up.

As Ernie navigates through the night streets, he observes Bert the cop stationed by his police car and discreetly signals to him, indicating the presence of a problematic passenger. Bert immediately understands and follows in his vehicle. When the taxi pulls up to the curb, George steps out to inspect a dilapidated house, temporarily halted by its state of disrepair, with windows shattered, the porch sagging, a roof section that has collapsed, and doors and shutters hanging askew. The police car arrives shortly after, and both Bert and Ernie keep a close watch on George, who approaches the house with a sense of foreboding, as if he is a man doomed to face an unfortunate destiny. Ernie switches on the cab’s spotlight, casting an eerie, ghostlike illumination on the house's interior, adding to the ominous atmosphere. George cries out, his voice resounding like a desperate plea for assistance. Suddenly, Clarence appears and leans against a wall just as Bert, with his gun drawn, stands poised at the entrance and rushes towards him, with Ernie right behind him, ready to support.

Bert attempts to take George away, but George resists, struggling to explain his situation. Frustrated, Bert raises his firearm with the intent of striking George. In a surprising turn, Clarence intervenes, biting Bert’s wrist, which creates an opportunity for George to break free from the house and sprint down the street. As Bert and Clarence wrestle, they tumble to the ground in a tangled heap. Bert, determined to subdue Clarence, tries to handcuff him, but Clarence mysteriously vanishes, leaving Bert astonished and baffled before he exits the scene. Meanwhile, George rushes up the path and urgently knocks on the door of the house.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The sequence of events unfolds in a captivating manner, beginning with an enchanting array of shots that beautifully capture and vividly bring to life the pulsating and vibrant nightlife of the bustling city. This nightlife is depicted through a colorful display of various night clubs, bustling cafes filled with the chatter and clinking of glasses, lively bars teaming with patrons, liquor stores overflowing with eager customers, and energetic pool halls. The atmosphere is alive with the dynamic and blaring sounds of jazz music reverberating through the night air. Amid this cacophony of nocturnal activity, Gower’s drugstore has undergone a significant transformation and now operates as a pawnbroker's shop. Meanwhile, the theater that once showcased motion pictures has been repurposed and converted into a lively house of burlesque. George finds himself halting in front of what once served as the offices of the Building and Loan, where a crowd has gathered with intense curiosity to witness the police in the act of conducting a raid. The officers, working with determined urgency, are forcefully dragging out women who vociferously scream in protest, including Violet Bick, who is conspicuously dressed in the flamboyant attire of a tart. George attempts to engage one of the police officers in a conversation, but his efforts are in vain as he is roughly shoved aside without a second thought. He then catches sight of Ernie’s taxi cruising by and promptly makes a signal, which results in the taxi coming to a halt to pick him up.

As Ernie skillfully navigates the winding streets that come to life at night, he glances around and spots Bert the cop, who is stationed dutifully by his police car. Discreetly, Ernie signals to Bert, effectively communicating the presence of a potentially problematic passenger. Bert instantly grasps the situation and follows in his vehicle, staying close behind. When the taxi finally pulls up to the curb, George steps out with a cautious demeanor to inspect a dilapidated house. He pauses momentarily, taken aback by its state of disrepair, which is evident from its broken windows, sagging porch, partially collapsed roof, and doors and shutters that hang loosely askew. The police car arrives shortly thereafter, and both Bert and Ernie keep a watchful eye on George, who approaches the house with a palpable sense of foreboding, as if he is a man condemned to face an inevitable, unfortunate destiny. Ernie switches on the cab’s spotlight, casting an eerie, ghostlike illumination on the interior of the house, which only serves to heighten the ominous atmosphere. George cries out, his voice echoing like a desperate plea for assistance. In that intense moment, Clarence suddenly appears, leaning casually against a wall just as Bert, with his gun drawn and ready for action, stands poised at the entrance and rushes towards him, with Ernie right behind him, prepared to lend his support.

Bert makes an attempt to take George away, but George resists, desperately struggling to convey and explain his dire situation. Growing frustrated, Bert raises his firearm with the clear intention of striking George. In an unexpected twist, Clarence intervenes just in time, biting Bert’s wrist, which creates a brief moment of opportunity for George to break free from the confines of the house and sprint down the street. As Bert and Clarence wrestle, they become entangled and tumble to the ground in a chaotic heap. Determined to subdue Clarence, Bert tries to handcuff him, but, in a mysterious turn of events, Clarence inexplicably vanishes, leaving Bert both astonished and utterly baffled before he finally decides to exit the scene. Meanwhile, George rushes up the path with urgency and begins knocking fervently on the door of the house.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The scene kicks off with a vivid montage of nighttime city life, depicting a variety of establishments—night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls—all pulsating with the energetic and intense blare of jazz music that fills the night air. Among the notable transformations, Gower's drugstore has now been converted into a pawnbroker's shop, while the building that once housed a motion picture theatre now operates as a burlesque house, signifying the changes in the neighborhood. George comes to a halt in front of what used to be the Building and Loan offices, where he discovers a chaotic scene: a crowd has gathered to witness the police conducting a raid. Women, their voices rising in screams, are being forcibly removed and dragged into a waiting patrol wagon; among them is Violet Bick, conspicuously dressed in revealing attire reminiscent of a tart. Spotting one of the police officers, George attempts to engage him in conversation but finds himself brusquely pushed aside, rendering his attempts futile. His attention is then caught by the sight of Ernie's taxi cruising along the road nearby; George raises his arm in a gesture to catch Ernie’s attention, and the taxi comes to a smooth stop at the curbside to pick him up. During the drive, Ernie's eyes dart ahead, spying Bert, a cop stationed by his police car. He subtly signals Bert, indicating with a nod and a gesture towards George in the backseat that there’s a passenger of concern. Bert, understanding the unspoken message, jumps into his patrol car and trails behind them. The taxi eventually glides to a gentle halt alongside the curb, and George deliberately steps out, his feet touching the ground heavily as he stands still momentarily, transfixed by the eerie sight of a house before him. Its decrepit state is immediately apparent—windows are shattered, the porch sags mournfully, a section of the roof has collapsed, and the doors and shutters hang crookedly from their hinges, completing the picture of neglect and decay. As George stands there, his expression reflects a mixture of despair and resignation, and the police car pulls up silently behind him. Both Bert and Ernie remain in their respective vehicles, their eyes intently watching George, who edges slowly towards the house, his posture and gait suggestive of a man condemned to face an unavoidable fate. Ernie reaches over and flips a switch, activating his taxi's spotlight, casting an ethereal, ghostly beam that penetrates the house's ruined interior, revealing its hidden depths. In a moment of emotional turmoil, George's voice pierces the night, his cry echoing as though he were voicing a desperate plea for assistance. At this critical juncture, Clarence emerges into view, subtly leaning against a wall. Bert, perceiving a potential threat, instinctively steps forward, brandishing his gun as he makes a rapid advance towards Clarence. Ernie, not wanting to be left behind, jumps out and rushes forward to back Bert up. Amidst the commotion, Bert earnestly tries to extricate George from the situation, but George, caught in his own whirlwind of explanations, resists. Bert, frustration mounting, prepares to subdue George with his firearm, only to be interrupted by Clarence, who unexpectedly lunges and sinks his teeth into Bert's wrist, causing him to recoil. This intervention grants George the precious seconds he needs to escape the confines of the house, propelling him into a sprint down the street’s stretch, while behind him, Bert and Clarence remain locked in a struggle, their bodies tangling and eventually collapsing onto the hard ground. In the ensuing scuffle, Bert attempts to regain control, reaching for his handcuffs to secure Clarence, but before he can act, Clarence performs a vanishing act, leaving Bert bewildered and astounded, staring at empty space before he collects himself and moves briskly out of the frame. Amidst the unfolding drama, George has already made his way up a familiar path, his feet pounding the pavement as he urgently approaches a door, knocking with a sense of urgency that resonates with the pounding of his heart.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The scene begins with shots of night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls blaring jazz music. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's, and the motion picture theatre is a burlesque house. George stops at the former offices of the Building and Loan, witnessing police raid the place and drag screaming women into a patrol wagon, including Violet Bick dressed provocatively. After a brief interaction with a cop, George is shoved aside and notices Ernie's taxi, which stops for him. As Ernie drives, he spots Bert the cop and signals him to follow due to a problematic passenger. Bert follows as the taxi parks, and George exits, confronted by a rundown house with broken windows and a sagging porch. With the police car arriving, Ernie uses his cab's spotlight to illuminate the house, casting a ghostlike glow inside as George cries out for help. Clarence leans against a wall inside, as Bert, gun ready, rushes toward him followed by Ernie. Bert tries to lead George away, but their struggle results in Bert raising his gun to strike George. Clarence intervenes by biting Bert's wrist, enabling George to escape. Bert and Clarence wrestle, but Clarence disappears, leaving Bert amazed as he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, George knocks on the house door.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting night clubs, cafes buzzing with artists and intellectuals, bars where locals gather to unwind, liquor stores stocked with an array of spirits, and pool halls emitting blaring jazz music reminiscent of the Roaring Twenties, a period known for its cultural dynamism. Gower's drugstore, once a community staple providing everything from sodas to prescriptions, is now a pawnbroker's establishment filled with items traded for cash in hard times, and the motion picture theatre, a former hub for cinematic escapism, has become a burlesque house known for its provocative performances. George stops before the former offices of the Building and Loan, a financial institution crucial to the town’s growth, where a crowd watches the police raiding the place, dragging screaming women into a patrol wagon, including Violet Bick, known around town for her flamboyant fashion, who is dressed as a tart. George talks to one of the cops, a figure representing law and order, but is shoved aside. He notices Ernie's taxi, a familiar yellow cab that’s been servicing the community for years, cruising by, which stops to pick him up. As Ernie drives, he spots Bert the cop by his police car, a patrol vehicle marked with the emblem of the local precinct, and signals him to follow, indicating a problematic passenger. Bert follows in his car as the taxi parks at the curb, and George exits to look at a house, a once-stately residence now in ruins, momentarily stopped by its dilapidated appearance with broken windows, sagging porch, fallen roof section, and askew doors and shutters. The police car arrives and Bert and Ernie watch George, who approaches the house like a doomed man facing a pivotal decision. Ernie uses his cab's spotlight to illuminate the house's interior ghostlike, casting eerie shadows. George cries out, appearing like a call for help to anyone who might understand his plight. Clarence suddenly leans against a wall as Bert, with gun in hand, stands in the entrance and rushes toward him. Ernie follows closely, ready to assist in his role as a concerned bystander. Bert tries to lead George away, but George struggles to explain, prompting Bert to raise his gun intending to strike George. Clarence intervenes, biting Bert's wrist, a sudden act of defiance, allowing George to escape the house and run down the street while Bert and Clarence wrestle, tumbling to the ground in a chaotic scuffle. Bert attempts to handcuff Clarence, but Clarence disappears, leaving Bert amazed before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, George runs up the path and knocks on the door of the house, seeking refuge or perhaps redemption within its familiar walls.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls emitting blaring jazz music. A cat's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's establishment, and the motion picture theatre has become a burlesque house. A squirrel stops before the former offices of the Building and Loan, where a crowd watches a cow raiding the place, dragging screaming women into a patrol wagon, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a tart. A squirrel talks to one of the dogs but is shoved aside. The squirrel notices a flamingo's taxi cruising by, which stops to pick him up. As the flamingo drives, it spots a rabbit the cop by his police car and signals him to follow, indicating a problematic passenger. The rabbit follows in his car as the taxi parks at the curb, and the squirrel exits to look at a house, momentarily stopped by its dilapidated appearance with broken windows, sagging porch, fallen roof section, and askew doors and shutters. The police car arrives and the rabbit and flamingo watch the squirrel, who approaches the house like a doomed man. The flamingo uses his cab's spotlight to illuminate the house's interior ghostlike. The squirrel cries out, appearing like a call for help. A penguin suddenly leans against a wall as the rabbit, with gun in hand, stands in the entrance and rushes toward him. The flamingo follows closely, ready to assist. The rabbit tries to lead the squirrel away, but the squirrel struggles to explain, prompting the rabbit to raise his gun intending to strike the squirrel. The penguin intervenes, biting the rabbit's wrist, allowing the squirrel to escape the house and run down the street while the rabbit and the penguin wrestle, falling to the ground. The rabbit attempts to handcuff the penguin, but the penguin disappears, leaving the rabbit amazed before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, the squirrel runs up the path and knocks on the door of the house.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting carnivals, diners, pubs, bookshops, and bowling alleys emitting blaring salsa music. Gower's bakery is now a toy shop, and the concert hall has become a circus tent. George stops before the former offices of the Music School, where a crowd watches the security guards raiding the place, dragging screaming performers into a delivery truck, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a juggler. George talks to one of the guards but is shoved aside. He notices Ernie's mechanical bull cruising by, which stops to pick him up. As Ernie rides, he spots Bert the guard by his motorbike and signals him to follow, indicating a problematic rider. Bert follows on his motorbike as the mechanical bull parks at the curb, and George exits to look at a shack, momentarily stopped by its ramshackle appearance with shattered windows, bending porch, collapsed roof section, and crooked doors and shutters. The motorbike arrives and Bert and Ernie watch George, who approaches the shack like a doomed man. Ernie uses his bull's spotlight to illuminate the shack's interior ghostlike. George cries out, appearing like a call for help. Clarence suddenly leans against a fence as Bert, with flashlight in hand, stands in the entrance and rushes toward him. Ernie follows closely, ready to assist. Bert tries to lead George away, but George struggles to explain, prompting Bert to raise his flashlight intending to strike George. Clarence intervenes, biting Bert's wrist, allowing George to escape the shack and run down the lane while Bert and Clarence wrestle, falling to the ground. Bert attempts to handcuff Clarence, but Clarence disappears, leaving Bert amazed before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, George runs up the path and knocks on the door of the mansion.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, and pool halls whispering gentle classical music. Gower's drugstore is now an art gallery, and the motion picture theatre has become a dance studio. George dances before the former offices of the Building and Loan, where a crowd observes the police organizing the place, guiding laughing women into a parade float, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a flapper. George chats with one of the cops but is twirled aside. He notices Ernie's taxi strolling by, which slows to collect him. As Ernie navigates, he observes Bert the cop by his police car and waves him to accompany, indicating a peculiar passenger. Bert follows in his car as the taxi halts at the curb, and George disembarks to admire a house, momentarily amused by its pristine appearance with shining windows, sturdy porch, restored roof section, and aligned doors and shutters. The police car arrives, and Bert and Ernie gaze at George, who approaches the house like an eager man. Ernie utilizes his cab's spotlight to highlight the house's interior warmly. George laughs out, appearing like a call of joy. Clarence suddenly leans on a railing as Bert, with a hat in hand, stands in the entrance and strolls toward him. Ernie trails closely, eager to join. Bert tries to escort George away, but George strives to dance, prompting Bert to lift his hat intending to crown George. Clarence intervenes, tickling Bert's wrist, allowing George to exit the house and skip down the street while Bert and Clarence embrace, collapsing to the ground. Bert attempts to handshake Clarence, but Clarence vanishes, leaving Bert astonished before he strolls out of the scene. Meanwhile, George skips up the path and rings the bell of the house.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting bookstores, bakeries, gardens, candy shops, and bowling alleys emitting blaring opera music. Valerie's bakery is now a tailor's establishment, and the concert hall has become a comedy club. Helen stops before the former offices of the Shipping and Receiving, where a committee watches the firefighters evacuating the place, dragging shouting clowns into a delivery truck, including Daisy Smith, who is dressed as a queen. Helen talks to one of the dancers but is pushed aside. She notices Sam's bicycle pedaling by, which stops to pick her up. As Sam pedals, he spots Max the gardener by his garden cart and signals him to follow, indicating an unruly passenger. Max follows in his cart as the bicycle parks at the corner, and Helen exits to look at a barn, momentarily stopped by its dilapidated appearance with shattered mirrors, drooping balcony, collapsed chimney stack, and crooked gates and blinds. The garden cart arrives and Max and Sam watch Helen, who approaches the barn like a brave warrior. Sam uses his bicycle's headlight to illuminate the barn's interior ghostlike. Helen cries out, appearing like a cry for assistance. Norman suddenly leans against a post as Max, with flashlight in hand, stands in the doorway and rushes toward him. Sam follows closely, ready to support. Max tries to lead Helen away, but Helen struggles to explain, prompting Max to raise his flashlight intending to strike Helen. Norman intervenes, flicking Max's wrist, allowing Helen to escape the barn and run down the trail while Max and Norman wrestle, falling to the ground. Max attempts to handcuff Norman, but Norman vanishes, leaving Max bewildered before he runs out of the scene. Meanwhile, Helen runs up the trail and knocks on the door of the barn.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene begins with a series of shots depicting libraries, galleries, bakeries, antique shops, and dance studios emitting soft rock music. Simmons's stationery store is now a jeweler's establishment, and the ice cream parlor has become a comedy club. Frank pauses before the former offices of the Manufacturing Company, where a group observes the fire department inspecting the area, dragging delighted children into a fire truck, including Emily Clark, who is dressed as a mime. Frank converses with one of the firefighters but is pushed back. He notices Sam's delivery van rolling by, which halts to pick him up. As Sam maneuvers, he notices Tom the delivery guy by his moped and signals him to follow, indicating an unusual parcel. Tom follows on his moped as the van pauses at the curb, and Frank exits to gaze at a library, hesitantly halted by its overgrown appearance with dusty books, tangled garden, collapsed fence, and crooked signage and awnings. The moped arrives and Tom and Sam observe Frank, who approaches the library like an intrigued guest. Sam uses his van's spotlight to highlight the library's interior eerily. Frank exclaims, appearing like an expression of wonder. Winston suddenly rests against a pillar as Tom, with flashlight in hand, stands at the entrance and rushes toward him. Sam follows closely, eager to help. Tom tries to guide Frank away, but Frank struggles to illustrate, prompting Tom to raise his flashlight intending to alarm Frank. Winston intervenes, tugging Tom's sleeve, allowing Frank to slip out of the library and dart down the path while Tom and Winston scuffle, tumbling to the path. Tom attempts to capture Winston, but Winston vanishes, leaving Tom bewildered before he sprints out of the area. Meanwhile, Frank dashes up the hill and taps on the window of the library.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The scene commences with a montage of shots depicting bookshops, diners, galleries, flower shops, and bowling alleys echoing with roaring classical music. Gower's pharmacy is now a baker’s emporium, and the cinema has turned into a ballet studio. George halts before the former offices of the Building and Loan, where a gathering observes the firefighters extinguishing the flames, herding laughing children into a fire truck, including Violet Bick, who is dressed as a clown. George converses with one of the firefighters but is pushed aside. He notices Ernie's bicycle gliding past, which halts to scoop him up. As Ernie pedals, he spots Bert the mailman by his delivery van and gestures him to follow, indicating an unusual package. Bert follows in his van as the bicycle stops by the sidewalk, and George dismounts to admire a park, momentarily startled by its untouched wilderness with overgrown grass, twisted trees, fallen branches, and scattered leaves and litter. The delivery van arrives, and Bert and Ernie observe George, who approaches the park like a curious explorer. Ernie uses his bike’s headlamp to spotlight the park’s interior eerily. George exclaims, sounding like a cheer of excitement. Clarence suddenly leans against a fence as Bert, camera in hand, stands at the entrance and dashes toward him. Ernie trails closely, eager to assist. Bert attempts to guide George away, but George struggles to narrate, prompting Bert to lift his camera intending to photograph George. Clarence intervenes, pulling Bert’s collar, allowing George to depart the park and sprint down the sidewalk while Bert and Clarence tumble, sprawling onto the grass. Bert tries to wrap Clarence in a picnic blanket, but Clarence vanishes, leaving Bert astounded before he dashes out of the setting. Meanwhile, George jogs up the trail and taps on the gate of the park.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The spectacle unfolds with a sequence of takes showcasing theme parks, diners, shops, candy factories, and bowling alleys emitting wailing opera tunes. Mervin's bakery is now a jeweler's outlet, and the dance studio has transformed into a circus tent. Frank pauses in front of the former clubhouse of the Hiking and Camping Club, where a mob observes the firefighters inspecting the grounds, escorting howling penguins into a paddy wagon, including Larry Finch, who is garbed as a clown. Frank converses with one of the guards but is nudged away. He observes Jessica's limousine gliding past, which halts to collect him. As Jessica chauffeurs, she notices Tony the guard near his fire truck and gestures for him to follow, indicating a troublesome guest. Tony trails in his vehicle as the limo halts at the shoulder, and Frank steps out to inspect a castle, temporarily halted by its decrepit visage with shattered lanterns, sagging balcony, collapsed spire piece, and crooked gates and blinds. The fire truck arrives and Tony and Jessica observe Frank, who approaches the castle like a defeated traveler. Jessica employs her limo's floodlight to reveal the castle's spectral interior. Frank shouts, seeming like a plea for assistance. Gerald suddenly leans against a tree as Tony, with flashlight in hand, appears at the gate and dashes toward him. Jessica trails closely, prepared to assist. Tony attempts to guide Frank away, but Frank struggles to clarify, prompting Tony to lift his flashlight intending to strike Frank. Gerald intervenes, tickling Tony's wrist, allowing Frank to flee the castle and sprint down the path while Tony and Gerald grapple, tumbling to the ground. Tony endeavors to shackle Gerald, but Gerald vanishes, leaving Tony baffled before he exits the scene. Meanwhile, Frank darts up the trail and taps on the door of the castle.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The scene unfolds with vibrant shots of night clubs, bars, and pool halls playing loud jazz. Gower's drugstore is now a pawn shop, and the cinema has turned into a burlesque house. George observes the former Building and Loan office, witnessing a police raid involving Violet Bick. Approaching a cop, George is brushed off but then picked up by Ernie’s taxi. Spotting Bert the cop, Ernie signals him to follow due to a troublesome passenger. Arriving at a decrepit house, George hesitantly approaches as Ernie lights it up with his cab. George cries out, seemingly for help. Clarence appears, and Bert rushes in with his gun. As George struggles to explain, Clarence intervenes by biting Bert's wrist, allowing George to flee. Bert and Clarence tussle, with Clarence disappearing, leaving Bert astonished. George then races to knock on the house door.
